data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We are also measuring candidate psychological process measures such as shame and guilt. We do not have a priori hypotheses about these variables.

sample.value: We are planning on 100 participants per condition.

analyses.value: We will conduct two Anvovas with the payment mechanism and store environment and their interaction predicting the number of healthy and the number of branded items purchased. We will then compare the contrast between the four conditions. We hypothesize that in the condition in which participants use EBT in the high status environment they will choose less healthy and less branded items than the other conditions.

outliers.value: We have no pre-planned exclusions. However, we will not include the data of any participants who do not follow the instructions provided.

dependent.value: Participants are given 10 credits on an EBT (vs. control) card. They can spend 5 credits on two shelves, which represent two dependent variables. Shelf one contains 5 healthy and 5 unhealthy products. Shelf two contains 5 branded and 5 unbranded products. The variable of interest is the number of healthy (vs. unhealthy) products selected from shelf 1 (0-5) and the number of branded (vs. unbranded) products from shelf 2 (0- 5).

conditions.value:
Four conditions:

2 (Payment Mechanism: EBT vs. Control) X 2 (Store Environment: High vs. Low Status) between subject design.

hypothesis.value: Does the shopping location impact the types of products that are purchased when consumers use a EBT (vs. control) payment mechanism.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: EBT and Food Purchase

registration_responses.sample: We are planning on 100 participants per condition.
registration_responses.analyses: We will conduct two Anvovas with the payment mechanism and store environment and their interaction predicting the number of healthy and the number of branded items purchased. We will then compare the contrast between the four conditions. We hypothesize that in the condition in which participants use EBT in the high status environment they will choose less healthy and less branded items than the other conditions.

registration_responses.dependent: Participants are given 10 credits on an EBT (vs. control) card. They can spend 5 credits on two shelves, which represent two dependent variables. Shelf one contains 5 healthy and 5 unhealthy products. Shelf two contains 5 branded and 5 unbranded products. The variable of interest is the number of healthy (vs. unhealthy) products selected from shelf 1 (0-5) and the number of branded (vs. unbranded) products from shelf 2 (0- 5).
registration_responses.conditions:
Four conditions:

2 (Payment Mechanism: EBT vs. Control) X 2 (Store Environment: High vs. Low Status) between subject design.
registration_responses.hypothesis: Does the shopping location impact the types of products that are purchased when consumers use a EBT (vs. control) payment mechanism.

q1.value: Understanding and Enhancing Public Interpretation and Use of Probabilistic Tornado Warnings in the Southeastern United States Experiment II

q2.value: Chao Qin, Julie Demuth, Rebecca Morss, Susan Joslyn, Sonia Savelli, Kevin Ash

q3.value: Our project aims to explore several theoretical questions in visualized uncertainty communication. In Experiment II, we compare the effectiveness of the National Weather Service (NWS) Storm Based Warnings (SBW) for tornadoes to that of four proposed formats. For additional details on these formats, see the Method section. We are interested in examining whether providing people with numeric probabilistic information can lead to better decision quality and trust than providing deterministic information alone, in the context of visualized warnings. We are also interested in finding out whether people conflate the probability or likelihood of the forecast event with the severity or impact of the event, especially when presented with color-coded forecasts.

q4.value:
Please see the analysis plan document for a detailed description of hypothesis and predictions.

Hypothesis 1a: Understanding Likelihood
	We predict that participants understanding of tornado likelihood will be influenced by the forecast format. 

Hypothesis 1b: Misunderstanding – Confusion Between Likelihood and Severity
        We predict that numeric probabilistic conditions (Tabular and Probabilistic Text) will lead to better understanding than the color-coded condition (Red-Color) for which there will be evidence of conflation between likelihood estimates and severity estimates.

Hypothesis 1c: Misunderstanding – Influence of Max Probability
        Specifically, if the highest underlying probability in the forecast is higher (90% Max Probability) it will inflate likelihood ratings for values in that same forecast compared to when the highest underlying probability shown is lower (50% Max Probability) in Red condition. 

Hypothesis 2: Trust
	We expect that participants will have significantly greater trust in probabilistic formats than in the Polygon and Deterministic Text condition 

Hypothesis 3a: Decision Quality as measured by Expected Value
        We predict the difference between mean participant expected value and optimal mean expected value will be lower (indicating better decisions) in the probabilistic conditions than in the deterministic condition. 

Hypothesis 3b: Decision Quality as measured by the proportion of “shelter” decisions at each Underlying Probability Level
        We also predict that participants will be more conservative (i.e., shelter more often) in the Probabilistic conditions when the underlying probability is high, than in the deterministic conditions (Polygon and Deterministic Text) where no probabilistic information is given, and less often when the underlying probability is low, as observed in Experiment I.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: See the method section and the analysis plan document for details

q9.value:
See the method section document for details.
Trial order manipulation: We have four trial order presets (scrambled using random number generators). Participants are randomly assigned to one of the four order presets.
Question order manipulation: There are two question order presets: either likelihood rating is measured first or severity rating is measured first. Participants are randomly assigned to one of the presets.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We have collected the data by the end of 2019 and had to go through an elimination process due to some Amazon M-Turk participants using scripts to automatically complete the task without the use of human intelligence. We used the attention check question, probability check questions, and text entry question in each trial (see method section for description of these questions) to detect script users and non-attentive participants. None of these three questions will be analyzed in our planned apriori tests. We have not observed any dependent variables that will be involved in our analysis.

question.value:
See method section and elimination criteria for details. We used Amazon M-Turk platform to publish our task and acquire human subject data. Our recruitment criteria are:
1. Location is inside the US
2. Approval rate of task completions from all M-Turk requesters must be 98% or more
3. Number of approved task completions from all M-Turk requesters must be 100 or more.

data.name: Elimination Criteria for E2 MTurk Experiment 1.8.2020.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Elimination Criteria for E2 MTurk Experiment 1.8.2020.docx

q13.value: See the elimination document for detail. A total of 302 M-Turk participants completed the task. Only data for 276 participants remained after elimination of non-attentive participants and script users.

question.value:
See method section and analysis plan for detail.
Between-subject variables:
1. In order to rule out order effects, we created four trial order presets (scrambled using random number generators) and two question order presets (either likelihood rating is measured first or severity rating). Participants are randomly assigned to a trial order preset and a question order preset.
2. The five tornado warning formats are manipulated between-subject. Each participant is only exposed to one format.
3. Uncertainty: the formats can either have Probabilistic Information or Deterministic Information
4. Surrounding Information: the formats can either have information on the surrounding area or no such information
Within-subject variable:
1. We have six different underlying tornado probability levels. Each participant is exposed to all of them, with the order depending on the trial order preset they are assigned to.

See the method section document and the analysis plan document for detail.
Dependent variables that will be in the planned analysis:
1. participants' own likelihood estimation of the probability of a tornado happening at their location.
2. participants' own severity estimation of the potential tornado.
3. participants' trust ratings for each trial and the one final trust rating after all trials.
4. participants' decision to take the safety or risk option for each trial.
See the analysis plan for detail.

q23.value: We will either exclude participants with missing trial data or fill in the missing trial data with their average scores across trials.

data.name: Elimination Criteria for E2 MTurk Experiment 1.8.2020.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Elimination Criteria for E2 MTurk Experiment 1.8.2020.docx

q22.value: See the elimination document for detail.

q23.value: We will either exclude participants with missing trial data or fill in the missing trial data with their average scores across trials.

registration_responses.q1: Understanding and Enhancing Public Interpretation and Use of Probabilistic Tornado Warnings in the Southeastern United States Experiment II
registration_responses.q2: Chao Qin, Julie Demuth, Rebecca Morss, Susan Joslyn, Sonia Savelli, Kevin Ash
registration_responses.q3: Our project aims to explore several theoretical questions in visualized uncertainty communication. In Experiment II, we compare the effectiveness of the National Weather Service (NWS) Storm Based Warnings (SBW) for tornadoes to that of four proposed formats. For additional details on these formats, see the Method section. We are interested in examining whether providing people with numeric probabilistic information can lead to better decision quality and trust than providing deterministic information alone, in the context of visualized warnings. We are also interested in finding out whether people conflate the probability or likelihood of the forecast event with the severity or impact of the event, especially when presented with color-coded forecasts.
registration_responses.q4:
Please see the analysis plan document for a detailed description of hypothesis and predictions.

Hypothesis 1a: Understanding Likelihood
	We predict that participants understanding of tornado likelihood will be influenced by the forecast format. 

Hypothesis 1b: Misunderstanding – Confusion Between Likelihood and Severity
        We predict that numeric probabilistic conditions (Tabular and Probabilistic Text) will lead to better understanding than the color-coded condition (Red-Color) for which there will be evidence of conflation between likelihood estimates and severity estimates.

Hypothesis 1c: Misunderstanding – Influence of Max Probability
        Specifically, if the highest underlying probability in the forecast is higher (90% Max Probability) it will inflate likelihood ratings for values in that same forecast compared to when the highest underlying probability shown is lower (50% Max Probability) in Red condition. 

Hypothesis 2: Trust
	We expect that participants will have significantly greater trust in probabilistic formats than in the Polygon and Deterministic Text condition 

Hypothesis 3a: Decision Quality as measured by Expected Value
        We predict the difference between mean participant expected value and optimal mean expected value will be lower (indicating better decisions) in the probabilistic conditions than in the deterministic condition. 

Hypothesis 3b: Decision Quality as measured by the proportion of “shelter” decisions at each Underlying Probability Level
        We also predict that participants will be more conservative (i.e., shelter more often) in the Probabilistic conditions when the underlying probability is high, than in the deterministic conditions (Polygon and Deterministic Text) where no probabilistic information is given, and less often when the underlying probability is low, as observed in Experiment I.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9:
See the method section document for details.
Trial order manipulation: We have four trial order presets (scrambled using random number generators). Participants are randomly assigned to one of the four order presets.
Question order manipulation: There are two question order presets: either likelihood rating is measured first or severity rating is measured first. Participants are randomly assigned to one of the presets.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: We have collected the data by the end of 2019 and had to go through an elimination process due to some Amazon M-Turk participants using scripts to automatically complete the task without the use of human intelligence. We used the attention check question, probability check questions, and text entry question in each trial (see method section for description of these questions) to detect script users and non-attentive participants. None of these three questions will be analyzed in our planned apriori tests. We have not observed any dependent variables that will be involved in our analysis.
registration_responses.q13: See the elimination document for detail. A total of 302 M-Turk participants completed the task. Only data for 276 participants remained after elimination of non-attentive participants and script users.
registration_responses.q22: See the elimination document for detail.
registration_responses.q23: We will either exclude participants with missing trial data or fill in the missing trial data with their average scores across trials.
registration_responses.q8.question: See the method section and the analysis plan document for details
registration_responses.q12.question:
See method section and elimination criteria for details. We used Amazon M-Turk platform to publish our task and acquire human subject data. Our recruitment criteria are:
1. Location is inside the US
2. Approval rate of task completions from all M-Turk requesters must be 98% or more
3. Number of approved task completions from all M-Turk requesters must be 100 or more.

q12.uploader.file_name: Elimination Criteria for E2 MTurk Experiment 1.8.2020.docx

registration_responses.q16.question:
See method section and analysis plan for detail.
Between-subject variables:
1. In order to rule out order effects, we created four trial order presets (scrambled using random number generators) and two question order presets (either likelihood rating is measured first or severity rating). Participants are randomly assigned to a trial order preset and a question order preset.
2. The five tornado warning formats are manipulated between-subject. Each participant is only exposed to one format.
3. Uncertainty: the formats can either have Probabilistic Information or Deterministic Information
4. Surrounding Information: the formats can either have information on the surrounding area or no such information
Within-subject variable:
1. We have six different underlying tornado probability levels. Each participant is exposed to all of them, with the order depending on the trial order preset they are assigned to.
registration_responses.q17.question:
See the method section document and the analysis plan document for detail.
Dependent variables that will be in the planned analysis:
1. participants' own likelihood estimation of the probability of a tornado happening at their location.
2. participants' own severity estimation of the potential tornado.
3. participants' trust ratings for each trial and the one final trust rating after all trials.
4. participants' decision to take the safety or risk option for each trial.
registration_responses.q19.question: See the analysis plan for detail.

attributes.title: Demographic Change & Targeting Women Online - YouGov Wave 3

attributes.title: Character Strength Use for Self vs. Others

q1.value: Character Strength Use for Self vs. Others

q2.value: Ayse Yemiscigil, Ashley Whillans, Matthew Lee

q3.value: Character strengths are widely valued behavioral tendencies that are authentic, energizing, and enable optimal functioning (Linley 2008). Some examples of strengths are curiosity, humor, leadership and perseverance. When adolescents are asked to identify and use their strengths for personal aims, they report higher psychological well-being (Ghielen, van Woerkom, & Christina Meyers, 2017). Yet, the impact of strength use for self-growth vs. benefiting other people remains unexamined. This study sets out to test whether using strengths to benefit others vs. the self may have a different impact on facets of psychological well-being among adolescents.

q4.value:
Hypotheses about immediate effects 

H1: Planning about using character strengths for others vs. self will have a positive impact on sense of meaning and purpose. 

H2: Planning about using character strengths for others vs. self will have a negative impact on positive affect. 

H3: People will forecast that it will be more difficult to use character strengths for others vs. self. 

H4: People will be less likely to make commitments to use character strengths for others vs. self. 

Hypotheses about effects at a three-month follow-up: 

H5: Using character strengths for others vs. self will have a positive impact on all aspects of psychological well-being (sense of meaning and purpose, positive vs. negative affect, and life satisfaction).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Our experiment has a between-subjects design. Students will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: a control condition (identify strengths and engage in a task to plan for things you have to do at home next week), treatment condition 1 (identify strengths and plan for explicitly using them in goals and activities that are personally important to you), treatment condition 2 (identify strengths and plan for explicitly using them in goals and activities that will help other people in some way).

q9.value: Participants will be randomized into conditions at the individual-level through logic built into our Qualtrics survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.
 
The initial data collection for the study will occur in February 2020 where the experimental manipulation will take place and a follow-up study will be conducted about three months later to measure potential long-term effects

q13.value: The participants will be comprised of students from a high school in the US, as chosen by the CLRN, and sample size will reflect the maximum number of students who are eligible and available for testing within the allotted time provided by the high school. It is estimated that our study will have 1090 participants in each of the three conditions, in total 3270 students. The follow-up study will involve the same high school and sample, and therefore similar sample size.

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above.

question.value: We will manipulate assignment to condition. There will be three conditions: (1) planning for compulsory activities at home (control), (2) strength use for self (active control), (3) strength use for others (active intervention). Students will be randomly assigned, at the individual level, to one of these three conditions.

During the study, all groups will identify their character strengths using the VIA Youth Survey (ages 10 to 17).

Data will be collected on the following outcome measures immediately after the participants identify their strengths and at a two-three months follow-up:
1.	Overall life satisfaction will be assessed with a widely used single item question (Diener et al, 1985) “Overall, how satisfied are you with life as a whole these days?’ The responses will be rated on a scale from 0 - Not Satisfied at All to 10 - Completely Satisfied. 
2.	Positive and negative affect will be measured with a leading question ‘Now rate the following items for how you are feeling right now’ which will be followed by adjectives ‘Happy’, ‘joyful’ and ‘satisfied’ for positive affect and ‘sad’, ‘angry’, ‘worried’ or ‘afraid’ for negative affect. The responses will be rated on a scale from 1(Not at all true) to 7(Extremely true). The questions are adapted from Scale of Positive and Negative Experience (Diener et al., 2009)
3.	Meaning and purpose in life will be measured with a leading a question ‘Now rate the following items for how you are feeling right now’. This will be followed by a 5-item scale from the meaning in life questionnaire (Steger et al., 2006) (e.g., ‘My life has a clear sense of purpose.’, ‘I understand my life’s meaning.’ The responses will be rated on a scale from 1(Not at all true) to 7(Extremely true).
4.	Difficult: A question will ask ‘How difficult do you think it will be to complete what you have to do next week?’  (1-not at all difficult, 5-very difficult)
5.	Commitment: Participants will be asked to make a commitment by checking the box that says ‘I will commit to my planned activities next week and continue to do them in the future’

 We will also collect data on student grades, reduced/free lunch status and attendance.

We will average the items in each scale for i) meaning, i) positive affect, and ii) negative affect. To calculate a total score for positive affect, we will subtract total negative affect scores from positive affect.

To estimate the immediate treatment-of-the-treated effects, we will use instrumental variable analysis whereby the binary treatment status variable will be used as an instrument and compliance with strength use planning instructions will be used as an endogenous regressor. Well-being measures will be used as the dependent variable. Binary treatment status variable equals 1 if students are in ‘strength use for others’ condition and 0 if students are in the active control ‘strength use for self’ condition. We will also examine intent-to-treat estimates by regressing each outcome measure on the treatment status variable. 

To estimate the treatment-of-the-treated effects at the three-month follow-up, we will use instrumental variable analysis whereby the binary treatment status variable will be used as an instrument and compliance with strength use plans will be used as an endogenous regressor. Well-being measures will be used as the dependent variable. We will also examine intent-to-treat estimates by regressing each follow-up outcome measure on the treatment status variable.

Where applicable and relevant (e.g., if the conditions are not balanced on a certain characteristic), we will include control variables

q20.value: We will use z-scores for outcome measures in order to be able to interpret effect sizes for each outcome measure.

q21.value: Inferences of statistical significance will be based on p-values less than .05. We will use one-tailed tests.

q22.value: We will exclude participants who i) have given nonsensical and/or pejorative answers in the open-ended responses for the strength planning exercises or in the feedback form, and/or ii) have not completed the strength identification exercise at the beginning of the study, and/or iii) reported technical difficulties or distractions

q23.value: We will use imputation methods for missing data where possible.

q24.value:
We will conduct an exploratory test of how the strength use for others and the self-conditions compare the control group where participants make plans about their house duties with respect to well-being outcomes and academic outcomes of grades and attendance.
 
We will conduct an exploratory test of whether the results differ based on gender, age, and socio-economic status (measured by reduced/free lunch status), as well as baseline prosocial motivation (which will be measured by participants’ scores on prosocially-oriented character strengths such as love).

We will conduct an exploratory test of potential differential impact of strength use for others vs. self on grades and attendance. 

We will measure to what extent participants in the active control condition (strength use for the self) spontaneously make plans for using their strengths for others and this drives the differences across conditions.

This study sets out to test whether using strengths to benefit others vs. the self may have a different impact on facets of psychological well-being among adolescents.

attributes.title: Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task

q1.value: Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task

q2.value: Heidi Barkman, Marlee Salisbury, Theodore Bell, Christina M. Karns, Erik Knight, Eric Pakulak, Leslie E Roos, Elizabeth Skowron, Ryan Giuliano

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to replicate the results found by Giuliano, Skowron, and Berkman (2015) and to extend the empirical approach by measuring both branches of the autonomic nervous system. The data to be analyzed were previously collected during the Fall semesters of 2014, 2015, and 2016. Parent-child dyads completed a 2.5-hour lab visit wherein cardiac (electrocardiogram, ECG; impedance cardiogram, IC) and neural (electroencephalogram, EEG) measures were collected in parents and children throughout a variety of tasks. Approximately one hour after arriving at the lab, parents and children were seated next to each other and completed a 5-minute resting assessment of ECG and IC. Towards the end of the lab visit, children and their parent were again seated at a table together to complete a challenging puzzle task for 5 minutes, while ECG and IC were continuously recorded. A “moose” made of 11 Duplo blocks was set on the table in front of the child, and the child was given a set of the same 11 blocks, not yet constructed, and instructed to build a replica of the moose. Parents were instructed to verbally assist their child in completing the moose but were explicitly told to not touch the Duplo blocks. After 5 minutes, a research assistant entered the room and ended the task. Shortly afterwards, parents and children remained seated and completed a 5-minute resting assessment of ECG and IC before leaving the laboratory.

q4.value: We expect to replicate the finding that parents with low parenting quality assessments during a challenging puzzle task with their child will concurrently show diminished reactivity of high-frequency variability in heart rate at the respiration range, or heart rate variability (HRV), indexing less dynamic parasympathetic nervous system (PNS) activity. In an expansion from the previous study (Giuliano, Skowron, & Berkman, 2015), pre-ejection period (PEP) data will be analyzed as a measure of sympathetic nervous system (SNS) activity alongside concurrent measures of HRV. We predict that individuals with low SNS activity, at rest or during the task, will show a greater dynamic range of HRV reactivity to the task. Though exploratory, we anticipate that shortened PEP values to the task, indicative of heightened SNS reactivity, will be associated with low parenting quality.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This observational study will investigate the correlational relationship between parenting quality and autonomic physiological data.  Secondary analyses will be conducted on pre-collected pre-intervention assessment data from the Health and Human Services (HHS) study conducted at the University of Oregon.  Interactions between the factors will be considered while controlling for extraneous factors of influence.

data.name: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Mothers with a preschool-aged child were recruited in partnership with the local Head Start program in Lane County of Oregon.  Telephone screening was performed to establish participant eligibility.  Exclusionary criteria included that the mother was over 18 years of age, had primary custody over the 3- to 5-year-old child, and that both members of the dyad were fluent in English and had no medical history of head trauma or neurological disorders.  Participants were offered $150 compensation for taking part in the study.

data.name: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

q13.value: A total of 165 videos of the challenging puzzle task were collected throughout the HHS study, but 13 were recorded without sound due to experimenter error.  Of the remaining 152 useable videos, 25 were recorded in the Spanish language and will not be coded for the present analyses due to a lack of fluent Spanish-speaking Research Assistants (RAs) available.

question.value:
Autonomic nervous system activity and parenting quality are the main focuses of the present study. Autonomic function will be indexed via HRV (for PNS) and PEP (for SNS) scores obtained from ECG and IC signals during a 5-minute resting baseline task and during a subsequent 5-minute challenge task (see Brief Overview above for description of lab visit). For HRV, a frequency range of .15-.40 Hz will be used to quantify variability of heart rate in the respiration range for adults. Both HRV and PEP will be processed in 30-second epochs during each of the 5-minute tasks. Baseline HRV and PEP will be calculated as the average across all 30-second epochs during the 5-minute baseline task. Change scores of HRV and PEP, used as predictors in level one of the multilevel models, will be calculated for each 30-second epoch as HRV or PEP activity in that epoch subtracted by the baseline value for that measure.

The main deviation from the previous study by Giuliano et al. (2015) is that parenting quality will be assessed using a different observational coding scheme. For this study, we will be using a lab-developed coding scheme tailored to preschooler-caregiver interactions based on the model proposed by Stansbury and Sigman (2000). This model features specific codes for how parents scaffold children’s self-regulation regarding objects and emotions, which is especially relevant to this task. Parenting behaviors are operationalized from this coding scheme along dimensions of: negative emotion reactions, positive emotion reactions, escape or avoidance, expressive encouragement, controlling, distraction, collaborative problem solving, task strategizing, task directed, and reframing. Each of the 10 dimensions of parenting will be coded in 30 second epochs for the entirety of the challenge task and later averaged to yield task averages of parenting. Summary scores across all dimensions will be calculated as the overall measure of Parenting Quality. If there is evidence that task averages of specific dimensions show stronger associations with autonomic reactivity, these will be explored in follow-up analyses, including examination of whether a summary score of these specific dimensions best capture differences in HRV and PEP reactivity across individuals.

data.name: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

question.value:
Multilevel growth modeling will be performed based on the same equations used by Giuliano et al. (2015) with the goal of elucidating growth dynamics in HRV and PEP as a function of parenting. Given the structure of the growth models, separate models will be examined for HRV and PEP. The first level of each model will focus on individual changes in the physiological measure of interest over the course of a challenging puzzle task, with the second level representing the effects of age, socioeconomic status, and baseline physiological activity. Both linear and quadratic growth will be examined.

Growth Model 1a of HRV without PEP.
Level 1:	HRVchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(HRVbaseline-j) + b03*(HRVtask-j) + 
b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + u0j

Growth Model 1b of HRV with PEP.
Level 1:	HRVchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(HRVbaseline-j) + b03*(HRVtask-j) + b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + b06*(PEPbaseline-j) + u0j

Growth Model 2a of PEP without HRV.
Level 1:	PEPchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(PEPbaseline-j) + b03*(PEPtask-j) + b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + u0j

Growth Model 2b of PEP with HRV.
Level 1:	PEPchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(PEPbaseline-j) + b03*(PEPtask-j) + b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + b06*(HRVbaseline-j) + u0j

q25.value:
References

Giuliano, R. J., Gatzke‐Kopp, L. M., Roos, L. E., & Skowron, E. A. (2017). Resting sympathetic arousal moderates the association between parasympathetic reactivity and working memory performance in adults reporting high levels of life stress. Psychophysiology, 54(8), 1195-1208.

Giuliano, R. J., Skowron, E. A., & Berkman, E. T. (2015). Growth models of dyadic synchrony and mother–child vagal tone in the context of parenting at-risk. Biological psychology, 105, 29-36.

Stansbury, K., & Sigman, M. (2000). Responses of preschoolers in two frustrating episodes: Emergence of complex strategies for emotion regulation. The Journal of Genetic Psychology, 161(2), 182-202.

registration_responses.q1: Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task
registration_responses.q2: Heidi Barkman, Marlee Salisbury, Theodore Bell, Christina M. Karns, Erik Knight, Eric Pakulak, Leslie E Roos, Elizabeth Skowron, Ryan Giuliano
registration_responses.q3: The purpose of this study is to replicate the results found by Giuliano, Skowron, and Berkman (2015) and to extend the empirical approach by measuring both branches of the autonomic nervous system. The data to be analyzed were previously collected during the Fall semesters of 2014, 2015, and 2016. Parent-child dyads completed a 2.5-hour lab visit wherein cardiac (electrocardiogram, ECG; impedance cardiogram, IC) and neural (electroencephalogram, EEG) measures were collected in parents and children throughout a variety of tasks. Approximately one hour after arriving at the lab, parents and children were seated next to each other and completed a 5-minute resting assessment of ECG and IC. Towards the end of the lab visit, children and their parent were again seated at a table together to complete a challenging puzzle task for 5 minutes, while ECG and IC were continuously recorded. A “moose” made of 11 Duplo blocks was set on the table in front of the child, and the child was given a set of the same 11 blocks, not yet constructed, and instructed to build a replica of the moose. Parents were instructed to verbally assist their child in completing the moose but were explicitly told to not touch the Duplo blocks. After 5 minutes, a research assistant entered the room and ended the task. Shortly afterwards, parents and children remained seated and completed a 5-minute resting assessment of ECG and IC before leaving the laboratory.
registration_responses.q4: We expect to replicate the finding that parents with low parenting quality assessments during a challenging puzzle task with their child will concurrently show diminished reactivity of high-frequency variability in heart rate at the respiration range, or heart rate variability (HRV), indexing less dynamic parasympathetic nervous system (PNS) activity. In an expansion from the previous study (Giuliano, Skowron, & Berkman, 2015), pre-ejection period (PEP) data will be analyzed as a measure of sympathetic nervous system (SNS) activity alongside concurrent measures of HRV. We predict that individuals with low SNS activity, at rest or during the task, will show a greater dynamic range of HRV reactivity to the task. Though exploratory, we anticipate that shortened PEP values to the task, indicative of heightened SNS reactivity, will be associated with low parenting quality.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q13: A total of 165 videos of the challenging puzzle task were collected throughout the HHS study, but 13 were recorded without sound due to experimenter error.  Of the remaining 152 useable videos, 25 were recorded in the Spanish language and will not be coded for the present analyses due to a lack of fluent Spanish-speaking Research Assistants (RAs) available.
registration_responses.q25:
References

Giuliano, R. J., Gatzke‐Kopp, L. M., Roos, L. E., & Skowron, E. A. (2017). Resting sympathetic arousal moderates the association between parasympathetic reactivity and working memory performance in adults reporting high levels of life stress. Psychophysiology, 54(8), 1195-1208.

Giuliano, R. J., Skowron, E. A., & Berkman, E. T. (2015). Growth models of dyadic synchrony and mother–child vagal tone in the context of parenting at-risk. Biological psychology, 105, 29-36.

Stansbury, K., & Sigman, M. (2000). Responses of preschoolers in two frustrating episodes: Emergence of complex strategies for emotion regulation. The Journal of Genetic Psychology, 161(2), 182-202.
registration_responses.q8.question: This observational study will investigate the correlational relationship between parenting quality and autonomic physiological data.  Secondary analyses will be conducted on pre-collected pre-intervention assessment data from the Health and Human Services (HHS) study conducted at the University of Oregon.  Interactions between the factors will be considered while controlling for extraneous factors of influence.

q8.uploader.file_name: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

registration_responses.q12.question: Mothers with a preschool-aged child were recruited in partnership with the local Head Start program in Lane County of Oregon.  Telephone screening was performed to establish participant eligibility.  Exclusionary criteria included that the mother was over 18 years of age, had primary custody over the 3- to 5-year-old child, and that both members of the dyad were fluent in English and had no medical history of head trauma or neurological disorders.  Participants were offered $150 compensation for taking part in the study.

q12.uploader.file_name: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

registration_responses.q17.question:
Autonomic nervous system activity and parenting quality are the main focuses of the present study. Autonomic function will be indexed via HRV (for PNS) and PEP (for SNS) scores obtained from ECG and IC signals during a 5-minute resting baseline task and during a subsequent 5-minute challenge task (see Brief Overview above for description of lab visit). For HRV, a frequency range of .15-.40 Hz will be used to quantify variability of heart rate in the respiration range for adults. Both HRV and PEP will be processed in 30-second epochs during each of the 5-minute tasks. Baseline HRV and PEP will be calculated as the average across all 30-second epochs during the 5-minute baseline task. Change scores of HRV and PEP, used as predictors in level one of the multilevel models, will be calculated for each 30-second epoch as HRV or PEP activity in that epoch subtracted by the baseline value for that measure.

The main deviation from the previous study by Giuliano et al. (2015) is that parenting quality will be assessed using a different observational coding scheme. For this study, we will be using a lab-developed coding scheme tailored to preschooler-caregiver interactions based on the model proposed by Stansbury and Sigman (2000). This model features specific codes for how parents scaffold children’s self-regulation regarding objects and emotions, which is especially relevant to this task. Parenting behaviors are operationalized from this coding scheme along dimensions of: negative emotion reactions, positive emotion reactions, escape or avoidance, expressive encouragement, controlling, distraction, collaborative problem solving, task strategizing, task directed, and reframing. Each of the 10 dimensions of parenting will be coded in 30 second epochs for the entirety of the challenge task and later averaged to yield task averages of parenting. Summary scores across all dimensions will be calculated as the overall measure of Parenting Quality. If there is evidence that task averages of specific dimensions show stronger associations with autonomic reactivity, these will be explored in follow-up analyses, including examination of whether a summary score of these specific dimensions best capture differences in HRV and PEP reactivity across individuals.

q17.uploader.file_name: Preregistration of secondary analyses - Growth models of autonomic activity and parenting quality during a challenging task.pdf

registration_responses.q19.question:
Multilevel growth modeling will be performed based on the same equations used by Giuliano et al. (2015) with the goal of elucidating growth dynamics in HRV and PEP as a function of parenting. Given the structure of the growth models, separate models will be examined for HRV and PEP. The first level of each model will focus on individual changes in the physiological measure of interest over the course of a challenging puzzle task, with the second level representing the effects of age, socioeconomic status, and baseline physiological activity. Both linear and quadratic growth will be examined.

Growth Model 1a of HRV without PEP.
Level 1:	HRVchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(HRVbaseline-j) + b03*(HRVtask-j) + 
b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + u0j

Growth Model 1b of HRV with PEP.
Level 1:	HRVchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(HRVbaseline-j) + b03*(HRVtask-j) + b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + b06*(PEPbaseline-j) + u0j

Growth Model 2a of PEP without HRV.
Level 1:	PEPchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(PEPbaseline-j) + b03*(PEPtask-j) + b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + u0j

Growth Model 2b of PEP with HRV.
Level 1:	PEPchange-ij = b0j + b1j*(Timeij) + b2j*(Time2ij) + r

Level 2:	b0j, b1j, b2j = b00 + b01*(Parentingj) + b02*(PEPbaseline-j) + b03*(PEPtask-j) + b04*(Agej) + b05*(SESj) + b06*(HRVbaseline-j) + u0j

attributes.title: Mental health project for Wuhan coronavirus outbreak

summary.value: This is an open-ended project. We aim to investigate the social-psychological factors that may affect people living in Wuhan, where China's coronavirus outbreak began. By a two-wave longitudinal design, we plan to recruit participants from the internet and collected data using the doctor-patient trust scale, risk perception scale, and consumer purchase items. The results will contribute to public health and epidemiological research.

registration_responses.summary: This is an open-ended project. We aim to investigate the social-psychological factors that may affect people living in Wuhan, where China's coronavirus outbreak began. By a two-wave longitudinal design, we plan to recruit participants from the internet and collected data using the doctor-patient trust scale, risk perception scale, and consumer purchase items. The results will contribute to public health and epidemiological research.
